questions.question: ………………………. up, the thief ran away.
questions.description:
When we split the clauses we get:
The thief jumped up. He ran away. We can connect them with the present participle jumping.

questions.question: ………………………… he sat down to rest.
questions.description:
When we split the clauses we get:
He was tired. He sat down to rest.
We can combine them using being tired.

questions.question: William I defeated Harold …………………… was the successor of Edward the Confessor in
questions.description: We use who to refer to people.

questions.question: This town ……………………….. was once a prosperous sea-port is now a heap of ruins.
questions.description: We use which to refer to places and things.

questions.question: The young woman fainted ………………….. hearing the news of her husband’s death.
The police ………………………, the mob dispersed.
questions.description:
The two clauses are:
The police arrived. The mob dispersed. Here the clauses have different subjects. We can connect them using ‘having arrived’.

questions.question: ………………………… his foot, he stopped.
questions.description: He hurt his foot. He stopped. We can combine them using 'having hurt'.

questions.question: The cow provides milk ………………………… is a nutritious food.
questions.description: We use which to refer to things.

questions.question: His uncle ………………………. was a millionaire sent him to England for higher studies.
questions.description: That is not used in non-identifying relative clauses.

questions.question: Chaucer ………………………… was the first great English poet was born in
questions.description: That is not used in non-identifying relative clauses.

questions.question: Nobody knows ………………………… Homer, the great poet, was born.
He ………………………. does not work must starve.
questions.description: Only who can replace pronouns like he and she.
